abstract: North Dakota state officials advise anglers not to remove fingerlings from the James River.
snippet: North Dakota state officials advise anglers not to remove fingerlings from the James River.
lead_paragraph: Asian carp have been found for the first time in the James River in North Dakota, officials from the state game and fish department say. They range from fingerlings that might be this year's spawn to older fish of up to 20 pounds. Imported in the 1970s to control algae growth in aquaculture and wastewater treatment facilities, the carp soon escaped and are considered highly invasive species. [The Jamestown Sun]

headline.main: On Our Radar: Invasive Carp Reach North Dakota
